metadata.titleEn: High-resolution tropospheric NO2 VCDs over East Asia POMINO v2.0.1 (2004-2020))
metadata.description: This data set contains the high-resolution tropospheric nitrogen dioxide vertical column concentration pomino v2.0.1 data in East Asia from 2004 to 2020, which provides an important data basis for studying the spatial distribution characteristics and temporal variation trend of tropospheric nitrogen dioxide in China. Based on the tropospheric nitrogen dioxide slant column concentration provided by KNMI, the pomino tropospheric nitrogen dioxide vertical column concentration is calculated through the tropospheric AMF retrieval algorithm developed by ourselves. The comparison with the ground-based observation data shows that the tropospheric nitrogen dioxide column concentration of pomino can better capture the day-to-day variation trend, and has better correlation with the ground-based observation data. At present, the data has been used for scientific research by many universities and scientific research institutions at home and abroad. In the future, the data set will provide more comprehensive data support for scientific research projects on the Qinghai Tibet Plateau.
metadata.instructions:
The file name is pomino monthly_ Yyyymm, where yyyy represents year and mm represents month.
Data reading method: all data in the data set are binary files, which can be opened and read in Python. For specific reading scripts, please refer to the  http://www.pku-atmos-acm.org/acmProduct.php/#POMINO

background: The retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCD from OMI is done by dividing the tropospheric slant column density (SCD) by the tropospheric air mass factor (AMF). Current representative OMI products covering China, DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2, do not explicitly account for the effect of aerosols on the solar radiation. Since aerosols affect the radiation field in retrieving both clouds and NO2, the net effect on the retrieved NO2 columns is unclear. This aerosol issue is particularly significant over East China due to its high aerosol loadings. In addition, the DOMINO and OMNO2 products also assume Lambertian surface with no dependence of surface reflectance on the geometry of the light path. DOMINO and OMNO2 adopt the vertical profile of NO2 simulated by coarse-resolution global chemical transport models (CTMs), TM4 at 3° long. × 2° lat. for DOMINO v2 and GMI at 2.5° long. × 2° lat. for OMNO2 v2, which are unable to capture the variability of NO2 at smaller scales.
research objective: Here we quantify the influences over China via an improved retrieval process.
methods: We explicitly account for aerosol optical effects (simulated by nested GEOS-Chem at 0.667° long. × 0.5° lat. and constrained by aerosol measurements), surface reflectance anisotropy, and high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 (simulated by GEOS-Chem). Prior to the NO2 retrieval, we derive the cloud information using consistent ancillary assumptions. We compare our retrieval to the widely used DOMINO v2 product, using MAX-DOAS measurements at three urban/suburban sites in East China as reference and focusing the analysis on the 127 OMI pixels (in 30 days) closest to the MAX-DOAS sites.
dataset: The MAX-DOAS measurements were conducted at three urban/suburban sites in East China, one at the Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in urban Beijing, one in Xianghe County to the southeast of Beijing, and one in the city of Tai’An. For all sites, the VCD of NO2 is retrieved from the radiation measurements around 477 nm. The total retrieval uncertainty on the tropospheric NO2 column has been estimated at 11% for the Beijing and Xianghe sites (Hendrick et al., 2013) and 14% for the Tai’An site (Irie et al., 2012).
findings: We find that our retrieval reduces the interference of aerosols on the retrieved cloud properties, thus enhancing the number of valid OMI pixels by about 25%. Compared to DOMINO v2, our retrieval better captures the day-to-day variability in MAX-DOAS NO2 data (R2 = 0.96 versus 0.72), due to pixel-specific radiative transfer calculations rather than the use of a look-up table, explicit inclusion of aerosols, and consideration of surface reflectance anisotropy. Our retrieved NO2 columns are 54% of the MAX-DOAS data on average, reflecting the inevitable spatial inconsistency between the two types of measurement, errors in MAX-DOAS data, and uncertainties in our OMI retrieval related to aerosols and vertical profile of NO2.

background: Tropospheric vertical column densities (VCDs) of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) retrieved from the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) on board the Earth Observing System (EOS) Aura satellite have been widely used to monitor and analyze NOx pollution over China because of their high spatiotemporal coverage. However, NO2 retrieved from OMI and other spaceborne instruments is subject to errors in the conversion process from radiance to VCD, particularly with respect to the calculation of tropospheric air mass factor (AMF) that is used to convert tropospheric slant column density (SCD) to VCD. Most current-generation NO2 algorithms do not explicitly account for the effects of aerosols on NO2 AMFs and on prerequisite cloud parameter retrievals. In polluted situations with high aerosol loadings and more absorbing aerosol types, which often occur over China and many other developing regions, the implicit method can result in considerable biases. Lin et al. (2014b, 2015) established the POMINO NO2 algorithm, which builds on the DOMINO v2 algorithm (for OMI NO2 slant columns and stratospheric correction), but improves upon it through a more sophisticated AMF calculation over China. The CALIOP lidar, carried on the sun synchronous CALIPSO satellite, has been acquiring global aerosol extinction profiles since June 2006.
research objective: This study improves upon the POMINO algorithm by incorporating CALIOP monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles to correct for model biases. Here we present a major algorithm update, POMINO v1.1, by constructing a monthly climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles, based on level 2 CALIOP/CALIPSO data over 2007–2015, to better constrain the modeled aerosol vertical profiles.
methods: Here we construct a custom monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles based on 9 years (2007–2015) worth of CALIOP version 3 level 2 532 nm data. We then use the corrected GEOS-Chem vertical extinction profiles in the retrievals of cloud parameters and NO2. As detailed in Appendix B, we use the daily all-sky version 3 CALIOP level 2 aerosol profile product aerosol at 532 nm from 2007 to 2015 to construct a monthly level 3 climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles over China and nearby regions. Our POMINO algorithm focuses on the tropospheric AMF calculation over China and nearby regions, taking the tropospheric SCD from DOMINO v2. POMINO v1.1 (this work) further uses CALIOP data to constrain the shape of the aerosol vertical extinction profile. We run the model at a resolution of 0.3125° long ×0.25° lat before May 2013 and 0.667° long ×0.5° lat afterwards, as determined by the resolution of the driving meteorological fields. We then regrid the finer-resolution model results to 0.667° long ×0.5° lat, to be consistent with the CALIOP data grid.
dataset: CALIOP is a dual-wavelength polarization lidar measuring attenuated backscatter radiation at 532 and 1064 nm since June 2006. We use MAX-DOAS measurements at three suburban or urban sites in East China, including one urban site at the Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP) in Beijing, one suburban site in Xianghe County to the south of Beijing, and one urban site in Wuxi City in the Yangtze River Delta (YRD).
findings: The improved NO2 VCDs (in POMINO v1.1) are more consistent with independent ground-based MAX-DOAS observations (R2 =0.80, NMB =−3.4 %, for 162 pixels in 49 days) than POMINO (R2 =0.80, NMB =−9.6 %), DOMINO v2 (R2 =0.68, NMB =−2.1 %), and QA4ECV (R2 =0.75, NMB =−22.0 %) are. Especially on haze days, R2 reaches 0.76 for POMINO v1.1, much higher than that for POMINO (0.68), DOMINO v2 (0.38), and QA4ECV (0.34).

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that accounts for aerosol optical effects when measuring tropospheric NO2 concentrations?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method that accounts for aerosol optical effects is the use of a retrieval process that explicitly includes aerosol optical effects simulated by nested GEOS-Chem and constrained by aerosol measurements. This method improves the retrieval of NO2 by accounting for surface reflectance anisotropy and using high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that uses lidar technology to improve the retrieval accuracy of aerosol profiles in the context of NO2 concentration measurement?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is obtained using CALIOP, a dual-wavelength polarization lidar that measures attenuated backscatter radiation. This data is used to construct a monthly climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles, which is then incorporated into the POMINO algorithm to improve the accuracy of NO2 concentration measurements.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how high-resolution modeling is utilized in the context of NO2 data retrieval over East Asia?
Example.Answer: High-resolution modeling is utilized by employing the GEOS-Chem model at resolutions of 0.667° long. × 0.5° lat. to simulate high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2. This approach allows for more precise retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCD by capturing smaller scale variability, which is particularly important over regions like East China with high aerosol loadings.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of the Aerosol Mass Factor (AMF) in the retrieval of tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities (VCDs)?
Definition.Answer: The Aerosol Mass Factor (AMF) is crucial in the retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCDs as it converts the tropospheric slant column density (SCD) to VCD. Errors in the AMF calculation, particularly due to the effect of aerosols, can lead to biases in NO2 retrievals, especially in regions with high aerosol loadings such as East China.

Definition.Question: What role does the CALIOP lidar play in enhancing the accuracy of NO2 data retrieval over East Asia?
Definition.Answer: CALIOP lidar provides global aerosol extinction profiles that are used to construct a climatological dataset to correct aerosol vertical profiles in the POMINO algorithm. This helps in refining the NO2 data retrieval process by better constraining the shape of the aerosol vertical extinction profile, thus improving retrieval accuracy over East Asia.

Comparison.Question: How do the aerosol optical effects and surface reflectance anisotropy considerations in POMINO v2.0.1 compare to those in existing datasets like DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2?
Comparison.Answer: POMINO v2.0.1 explicitly accounts for aerosol optical effects and surface reflectance anisotropy, which are not explicitly considered in DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2. This results in a more accurate retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCDs over regions with high aerosol loadings, such as East China, by addressing the net effect of aerosols on the retrieved NO2 columns.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the spatial resolution and data sources used in POMINO v2.0.1 compared to the previous versions or other NO2 retrieval algorithms?
Comparison.Answer: POMINO v2.0.1 utilizes high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 simulated by GEOS-Chem and is constrained by aerosol measurements, providing a finer resolution (0.667° long. × 0.5° lat.) compared to the coarse-resolution global CTMs used in DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2. This allows POMINO to capture the variability of NO2 at smaller scales more effectively.

Interpretation.Question: How does the utilization of CALIOP lidar data in constructing aerosol vertical extinction profiles enhance the understanding of NO2 retrievals in the presence of aerosols?
Interpretation.Answer: Utilizing CALIOP lidar data allows for the construction of detailed aerosol vertical extinction profiles, which can correct model biases and improve the calculation of tropospheric air mass factors. This enhances the accuracy of NO2 retrievals by providing a more accurate representation of how aerosols interact with radiation, especially in high aerosol loading conditions, leading to more reliable and consistent NO2 vertical column density measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the retrieval process of tropospheric NO2 VCD from OMI to be influenced by aerosol optical effects over East China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCD from OMI is influenced by aerosol optical effects because current representative OMI products, like DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2, do not explicitly account for the effect of aerosols on solar radiation. This issue is significant over East China due to high aerosol loadings, which affect the radiation field in retrieving both clouds and NO2, leading to unclear net effects on the retrieved NO2 columns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do current-generation NO2 algorithms, when used in polluted regions like China, result in biases during the conversion process from radiance to VCD?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Current-generation NO2 algorithms result in biases in polluted regions because they often do not explicitly account for the effects of aerosols in the calculation of tropospheric air mass factors (AMFs) used to convert tropospheric slant column density (SCD) to VCD. In regions with high aerosol loadings, such as China, this implicit approach can result in considerable biases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use high-resolution vertical profiles and specific radiative transfer calculations when retrieving tropospheric NO2 columns over East Asia?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High-resolution vertical profiles and specific radiative transfer calculations are important to accurately capture the day-to-day variability of NO2 concentrations and reduce errors introduced by coarse-resolution models. This approach allows for a more precise understanding of NO2 distribution and trends, which is essential for assessing air pollution levels and their impact on public health and the environment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps taken to account for aerosol optical effects when retrieving tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities in high-pollution areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The retrieval process explicitly accounts for aerosol optical effects simulated by nested GEOS-Chem at high resolution and constrained by aerosol measurements. This involves calculating high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 and deriving cloud information using consistent ancillary assumptions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in validating satellite-derived NO2 data with ground-based measurements in urban and suburban settings?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation involves comparing the satellite-derived NO2 data with MAX-DOAS measurements taken at selected urban and suburban sites. The NO2 vertical column densities are retrieved from radiation measurements and the data's reliability is assessed by estimating retrieval uncertainties and comparing correlation coefficients between the datasets.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate retrieval of tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities in regions with high aerosol loadings?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 simulated by GEOS-Chem, along with accounting for aerosol optical effects and surface reflectance anisotropy, enables a more accurate retrieval of tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities. Additionally, the integration of CALIOP monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles helps correct model biases.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of ground-based MAX-DOAS measurements enhance the validation process for satellite-derived NO2 data?
Enablement.Answer: Ground-based MAX-DOAS measurements at urban and suburban sites in East China provide a reference that enhances the validation process for satellite-derived NO2 data by allowing for direct comparison and assessment of retrieval accuracy. This comparison helps identify the interference of aerosols and improve the correlation between satellite and ground-based observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for tropospheric NO2 VCDs not account for aerosol effects, and what are the anticipated outcomes of addressing this issue?
Expectation.Answer: Current representative OMI products covering China, such as DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2, do not explicitly account for the effect of aerosols on solar radiation, which is significant over East China due to high aerosol loadings. Addressing this issue by explicitly accounting for aerosol optical effects could improve the retrieval process by reducing biases and better capturing the variability of NO2 at smaller scales.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using aerosol optical effects and high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 in improving data collection accuracy for tropospheric NO2 concentrations over East Asia?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of aerosol optical effects and high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 significantly improves data collection accuracy by explicitly accounting for factors that affect the retrieval of NO2 columns. This method enhances the correlation with ground-based MAX-DOAS measurements and captures day-to-day variability more effectively compared to previous methodologies like DOMINO v2.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges of incorporating aerosol vertical extinction profiles into the retrieval process of NO2 VCDs, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Incorporating aerosol vertical extinction profiles presents challenges due to the need for accurate modeling of aerosol properties and their impact on radiation fields. These challenges can be addressed by utilizing datasets such as CALIOP for aerosol measurements, which help to correct model biases and refine the aerosol vertical profiles, thereby improving the accuracy of NO2 VCD retrievals.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how aerosol optical effects are accounted for in the retrieval of tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities.
Assertion.Answer: Aerosol optical effects are explicitly accounted for by simulating them using nested GEOS-Chem at a high resolution (0.667° long. × 0.5° lat.) and constraining them with aerosol measurements. This approach enhances the retrieval accuracy by considering aerosol impacts on the radiation field during both cloud and NO2 retrieval processes.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure how data from instruments like CALIOP is integrated into algorithms for better NO2 analysis.
Assertion.Answer: CALIOP data is used to construct a monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles, which helps correct model biases. This is done by utilizing CALIOP's dual-wavelength polarization lidar measurements to refine the modeled aerosol vertical profiles, thus improving the NO2 vertical column density retrieval by constraining the shape of the aerosol vertical extinction profile in the POMINO algorithm.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the spatial resolution of chemical transport models affects the retrieval of NO2 data.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial resolution of chemical transport models is crucial because coarse resolutions, like those used in DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2, cannot capture the small-scale variability of NO2. In contrast, using a higher-resolution model like GEOS-Chem allows for more accurate representation of NO2 vertical profiles, which improves the retrieval process by better capturing day-to-day variability and reducing spatial inconsistencies with ground-based measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the significance of using ground-based MAX-DOAS measurements as a reference for validating satellite-derived NO2 data in urban and suburban sites in East China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Ground-based MAX-DOAS measurements are significant for validating satellite-derived NO2 data as they provide a reference for assessing the accuracy of retrievals. In the context of East China, MAX-DOAS measurements at urban and suburban sites such as Beijing, Xianghe County, and Tai'An are used to compare with satellite data, demonstrating improved day-to-day variability capture and higher correlation coefficients when aerosol effects are explicitly considered.
